image.altText: A drone view of a big housing complex in Canberra with rooftop solar cells on the roofs.

props.synopsis: The ACT government architect insists proposed changes to planning rules allowing denser development in Canberra's suburbs will help "mums and dads" as much as big property developers.

title.children: Concern missing middle housing proposal could see 'hodgepodge' development

image.altText: An exterior shot of an ANU building.

props.synopsis: As the Australian National University grapples with its dire financial position, the first of several rounds of job cuts has been announced as the institution seeks to save $250 million by the end of the year, including $100 million from salaries.

title.children: 'Tip of the iceberg': First round of job cuts announced by ANU

image.altText: A photo of a crushed white powder in a small clear bag next to a measuring ruler.

props.synopsis: A public health alert is issued after a dangerous drug cocktail is found circulating in Canberra for the first time, sold as a counterfeit prescription anxiety medication.

title.children: Drug cocktail 'not previously found' detected in Canberra

image.altText: An image of a phone screen with a text message.

props.synopsis: Italian osteopath Daniele Caminiti is found to have sexually assaulted a Canberra patient before boarding a flight to Italy just days after his workplace began an investigation.

title.children: 'Jeopardise my entire career': Osteopath texts patient after assault

image.altText: A man waves to the crowd after a rugby league match

props.synopsis: Josh Papalii was a Raiders legend long before he broke the club's all-time appearances record but his greatest place in Canberra history may yet be unwritten.

title.children: Josh Papalii is making Raiders history but his greatest day may be yet to come

image.altText: An old black and white photo of sevevn people on horses.

props.synopsis: The Eddison family suffered terrible loss during World War II. A plaque near a Canberra shopping centre car park offers an insight into that moment in history.

title.children: The tragic reason Walter Eddison never answered his telephone

image.altText: ACT Magistrate Court

props.synopsis: Police charged the 30-year-old with attempted murder after a man's fingers were cut off by a machete. His application for bail was refused.

title.children: Man accused of attempted murder with machete denied bail

image.altText: A woman with classes in a green suit.

props.synopsis: The Canberra Institute of Technology appoints a new chief executive, a year after Leanne Cover resigned and was found to have engaged in corrupt conduct in her handling of consultancy contracts.

title.children: CIT hires new CEO following corruption saga

image.altText: Donald Trump, Melania Knauss, Jeffrey Epstein and Ghislaine Maxwell pose for a photograph in a party

props.synopsis: The bromance between President Donald Trump and billionaire Elon Musk blown up with an unsubstantiated accusation about the Epstein files. Here's what to know.

title.children: Elon Musk says Donald Trump is in the Epstein files — here's the background

image.altText: Jeremy Rockliff with a football.

props.synopsis: Does Tasmania have a government? Has the AFL team crumbled before it even started? The big stadium project, has that fallen over too? Yes, it has been a chaotic 72 hours — let's try to explain what just happened.

title.children: What just happened in Tasmanian politics? Let's try to explain

image.altText: An ASX board with ASX in focus and stock prices out of focus.

props.synopsis: The Australian share market is flat as investors weigh up the growing spat between Donald Trump and Elon Musk, and a long-awaited phone call between the US president and his Chinese counterpart. Follow live.

title.children: ASX flat after Trump-Musk feud triggers sell-off on Wall Street

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Australia market flat as US uncertainty weighs
Where to next for US tariff policy?
285m Tesla shares trade in one day

image.altText: A man in a formal suit stands in front of a PNG flag.

props.synopsis: Papua New Guinea's peak anti-corruption body is on the brink of implosion, senior staff say, as its Australian and New Zealand bosses accuse each other of criminal activity.

title.children: PNG police issue arrest warrant for Australian anti-corruption boss

image.altText: Man on horse statue in snow with leafless trees

props.synopsis: South-east Australia will collectively shiver this long weekend as a mass of polar air from sub-Antarctic waters brings several days of showers, highland snow and well below average temperatures.

title.children: Four-day winter storm to bring drought relief and snow

image.altText: A woman with her mouth wide open in a parliament ripping a piece of paper.

props.synopsis: New Zealand's parliament hands record suspensions to three Indigenous Māori MPs after they performed a haka to protest a controversial bill last year.

title.children: Māori Party MPs receive record suspensions over haka protest

props.synopsis: The Nationals leader and shadow trade minister say the Albanese government shouldn't trade away Australia's biosecurity to secure an exemption from US tariffs. Follow live.

title.children: Nationals accuse Labor of trading away biosecurity to appease Trump

liveBlogKeyEvents.title: Australian Robert Pether released from Iraqi prison after more than four years
Littleproud says importing beef that has been raised in Mexico, Canada is 'dangerous'
Albanese looks forward to face-to-face meeting with Donald Trump

image.altText: A middle aged white man and woman sitting on the couch, either side of their young adult daughter. She is wearing glasses

props.synopsis: NDIS participants report sudden cuts or reviews of plans by staff who don’t understand disability, while a legal service representing participants through appeals says it has experienced a surge in demand.

title.children: 'Absolute disbelief': Families say NDIS agency doesn't understand disability

image.altText: Film critics David Stratton and Margaret Pomeranz toast to their star on the Australian Film Walk of Fame.

props.synopsis: Plus remembering queer literature icon Edmund White and Baby Reindeer's creator is headed to Australia for a TV industry summit.

title.children: David and Margaret honoured with Walk of Fame star

image.altText: two men stand in front of a bright backdrop

props.synopsis: Hollywood co-stars and close friends Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman are new co-owners of Australia's SailGP team.

title.children: Ryan Reynolds and Hugh Jackman buy Australian sailing team

image.altText: Tyrese Haliburton defends Shai Gilgeous-Alexander's shot

props.synopsis: Both Indiana and Oklahoma City decided to trade away their best player, Paul Goerge, in the space of two years. The pair of trades set them on the path to meeting in this year's NBA Finals.

title.children: How a pair of trades featuring the same star created this year's NBA Finals

image.altText: Aziz Behich is congratulated by teammates

props.synopsis: Nobody will confuse the Socceroos' victory over Japan as anything other than the most desperate of smash-and-grab victories. But in the end, in the vibe-fuelled world of international football, does that even matter?

title.children: Japan had torn the Socceroos apart, but one magic moment changed the narrative

image.altText: A picture of blurred out drone on a concrete floor.

props.synopsis: From an election recount to rare beach finds, it was another big week in news. Test yourself on what you remember.

title.children: Weekly news quiz: A late election win, the Big Beautiful Bill and cunning cockatoos

image.altText: Man sits upon the engine of a wrecked WWII era bomber plane.

props.synopsis: Eight decades after it was last in the sky, and four since it was taken from the Papua New Guinean jungle, a restored World War II bomber returns to Port Moresby from Queensland.

title.children: Crash-landed and salvaged from the jungle, WWII bomber returns home

image.altText: Hands holding a baby platypus

props.synopsis: Platypuses in Royal National Park are thought to have been wiped out by an oil spill more than 50 years ago, but the iconic animals are bouncing back thanks to a relocation program.

title.children: More platypuses released in park where species is staging a comeback

image.altText: A minibus on its side in the dark.

props.synopsis: A Cowra man pleads guilty to half a dozen offences relating to a fatal 2023 crash in which an elderly man died after he was ejected from a minibus.

title.children: Driver pleads guilty over courtesy-bus crash that led to 84yo's death

image.altText: A photo of a white woman with blonde wavy hair cocking her head and looking thoughtful.

props.synopsis: Sara Glass' life was controlled by her husband and her rabbi. She had to fight her way out before she could embrace her sexuality.

title.children: Sara was raised to obey her husband and God. But she couldn't hide her sexuality

image.altText: An illustration of rows of houses in blue. One house with panels is connected to the two neighbouring properties.

props.synopsis: For all Australia's success in adopting rooftop solar, millions of people are missing out. Now a new trial is aiming to overcome that divide through trading.

title.children: Selling excess solar to your neighbour could shake up the energy market

props.synopsis: The BBC says its team of journalists and crew were "tied up, blindfolded, strip searched, interrogated and threatened."

title.children: BBC journalists held at gunpoint and strip-searched by Israeli military, says broadcaster

image.altText: Anthony Albanese and Donald Trump at press conferences in suits.

props.synopsis: A government source says beef is being positioned as a bargaining chip to help reset trade ties after the US imposed harsh tariffs on Australian exports.

title.children: Australia could bargain over partial US beef ban in Trump tariff talks

image.altText: anthony albanese points towards reporters outside parliament house in canberra

props.synopsis: Labor leaned into attacking Peter Dutton and was never afraid to name him. With Sussan Ley, the prime minister might adopt the Bob Carr approach.

title.children: Albanese unlikely to use his approach to Dutton with new opponent Ley

image.altText: man with red har and striped beanie and brown tshirt holds up grey furry rat in the grassy highlands and mountains behind.

props.synopsis: A species of giant rat, the size of a small terrier, has been documented in New Guinea's highlands for the first time.

title.children: Terrier-sized 'woolly' rat caught on camera for first time

image.altText: Professor Dieter Weber, Head of Royal Perth Hospital’s Trauma Service

props.synopsis: Royal Perth Hospital's head of trauma services says preventable e-scooter injuries are having lifelong effects on a huge number of patients, as the friend of a man who died after being hit by an e-scooter says his death was avoidable.

title.children: Trauma surgeon describes 'enormous' daily e-scooter toll in hospital

image.altText: the photo of a greyhound track with a board showing the names of the dogs

props.synopsis: The new track was spruiked as having animal welfare at its core, but several dogs have died as a result of injuries at the venue during pre-opening trials.

title.children: Greyhounds die from injuries before Queensland track officially opens

image.altText: A model of the lunar lander Resilience displayed at

props.synopsis: Japanese company ispace says it has not been able to contact its uncrewed Moon lander Resilience since its lunar touchdown attempt.

title.children: Japanese spacecraft goes down during attempted Moon landing

image.altText: A man in a button-up shirt speaking to a journalist.

props.synopsis: The NT's corrections minister has flagged more private guards may be contracted to manage a under-pressure prison network, but has shut down union concerns the system will be privatised in its entirety.

title.children: NT corrections minister says crime crackdown will 'break the cycle'

image.altText: A samurai sits on a horse looking over a valley, screenshot from Assassin's Creed Shadows

props.synopsis: A new study has found that players who engage in historic games like Assassin's Creed or Age of Empires are driven to keep learning after they put down the controller. So historians are stepping up.

title.children: Meet the historians making sure video games get their facts right
